bibl.title: Plains Cree Texts
bibl.series: Publications of the American Ethnological Society, Volume XVI

encodingdesc.p: This electronic document is oriented more toward representing those features that seem most likely to be relevant for grammatical analyses, rather than toward faithfully representing all the information available in the book.

list.item: 2014 06 10; KR; UTF-8, paragraph and sentence numbering, smart-quotes in English translations

p.seg: mihcêtinwah êh-wîhkwêstêkih , pêyak opwâsimôw êh-okimâwit . many tents stood in a circle, and a certain Assiniboine was the chieftain. LB on {opwâsimôw}: Although the record has often this form, my feeling is for {opwâsîmôw} with long {î} as normal.
kotak minah okimâwiw oskinîkiw ômah ôtênaw ; êwakô an îskwêw êh-miyosit . There was also another chief in that village, a young man; he had a handsome wife.
êkwah awa kotak okimâw omisi isiyîhkâsôw : takwahiminânâhtik . And that other chief's name was Cherry-Tree. LB on {takwahiminânâhtik}: Below, this is the name not of the chief, but of his son.
êkwah awa okimâw okosisah pêyakoyiwa ; This chief had one son;
mistahi sâkihêw , osâm êh-miyosiyit okosisah . he loved him very much, because his son was so handsome.
êkwah awa oskinîkiw wîscâsah wîcêwêw , tahkih êh-nôcihiskwêwêyit . Now, this youth went about with his cousin, who was always courting women.
awa iskwêw kâ-miyosit ocâhkosah êwakoni tahkih ê-wîcêwât . And that handsome woman always went about with her husband's sister.

seg.q: pakâhkam , nîscâs , kikah-nôcîhkawâw awa kâ-miyosit iskwêw .
seg.gloss: “Surely, my cousin, you ought to court this handsome woman.

p.seg: kîstah kimiyosin , itêw . You too are handsome,” he said to him.

seg.gloss: “No, Cousin;
too great a chief is her husband;
I respect him as a brave warrior;

p.seg: osâm niya nama wîhkâc niwâpahtên nôtinitôwin , êyak ôhci , itêw wîscâsa . as for me, never have I seen fighting, that is why,” he told his cousin.
piyisk tâpwêhtawêw , mistan êh-miyohot awa okimâw okosisah . at last he listened to him and put on his finest clothes, that chief's son.

kêtahtawê êh-kwâpikêt aw îskwêw kâ-miyosit , itohtêwak ôki oskinîkiwak , pêyak okimâw okosisah , pêyak otihkwatimah , êh-itohtêcik ôhi kâ-kwâpikêyit ôhi iskwêwa kâ-miyosiyit . Presently to where that handsome woman was drawing water went those young men, one the chief 's son, the other his sister's son; they went to where the handsome woman was drawing water.

êkwah awa omis îtwêw ;
hêy , takwahiminânâhtik , namoya ôtah êh-kapâtêskwêhk , itah kâ-pê-itohtêyin ! Then she spoke thus: “Hey, Cherry-Tree, it is not here that food is being served, seeing that you have come here!

seg.q: namoya ôtah ayâw mîkiwâhp , êkâ k-êsi-pakisâpiyin , iskwêwak osikâkwaniwâwa pisisik ê-wîh-kakwêh-wâpahtaman .
seg.gloss: Here is no tent, for you to be staring every moment, trying to see the women's calves.
Never have you gone on the war-path;

seg.q: ahpôh nnâpêm pêyakwâw itêh êh-itohtêt nama wîhkâc kiwâpahtên .
seg.gloss: not once even have you been to see where my husband goes.

p.seg: tâpwê nama kinêpêwisin ! itêw . Truly you have no shame!” she told him.
êkwah aw oskinîkiw mâtôw ; oskîsikohk nipiy ohcikawiw , ê-nêpêwisit . Then that youth wept; the water ran from his eyes for very shame.

kîtahtawê ômisiy itik wîscâsah :
nîscâs , êkâya nêpêwisi . Presently his cousin said to him, “Cousin, do not be ashamed.

seg.gloss: You have fine clothes; you have a handsome horse.
Your father cares lovingly for you;

p.seg: minah kiwâhkomâkanak kahkiyaw kisâkihikok , osâm êh-miyosiyin , itêw wîscâsah . and all your relatives love you, because you are so handsome,” he told his young cousin.
nama nântaw itik , osâm ê-nêpêwisit . The other answered him not at all, because he was too much humiliated.
êkwah kîwêw . Then he went home.
pimisin wîkiwâhk . He lay in the tent.
êh-pêhtahk awa kisêyiniw okosisah êh-itimiht , otinam ayôwinisah . When the old man heard what has been said to his son, he took some garments.

seg.gloss: “Here, my son, dress yourself;
do not be ashamed;
do nothing foolish to yourself.
This is no way to be.

seg.q: osâm nama wîhkâc kisîhkimitin nântaw kit-êtohtêyin ; osâm kisâkihitin .
seg.gloss: I never bid you go to the scenes I need not name; I love you too much.
Poor men are they who go on the war-path, for they hope to steal horses;
but you, your horse is handsome; he is fleet of foot.

p.seg: kîstah kimiyosin ; namoya kikitimâkisin , itêw okosisah . And you yourself are handsome; you are not poor,” he told his son.
nama nântaw itwêw aw oskinîkiw , osâm êh-nêpêwisit . The youth did not answer, for he was too deeply shamed.

êh-wâpaniyik , êh-mâh-mâcîwiht , kîtahtawê kîksêpâ kâ-pêhtahk ,
iyahciyiniwak ôtah sêskâmôwak kisiwâk mihcêt ! itwêwân . The next morning, as the men of that village were about to go out on the hunt, early he heard the cry, “Blackfoot are coming out of the woods close by, in great number!”
pêhtam . He heard it.
êkwah kêsiskotâtôwak ayîsiyiniwak , ê-wîh-kakwêh-nipahâcik ayahciyiniwah ôki opwâsimowak . Then the people went forth to the attack, for those Assiniboine meant to kill the Blackfoot.
êkwah awah okimâw wawêyîw ; sipwêpayiw . That chieftain, too, made ready for the fight; away he rode.

seg.gloss: “Take care of this son of ours, and of his horse.
- Do not go to any place, my son.
You are wealthy;

p.seg: kahkiyaw ôhih kêkway kâ-miywâsikih kiya kitâyân , itêw okosisah . all things that are good, you have them,” he told his son.
êhag , itik okosisah . “Yes,” his son answered him.
aspin sipwêhtêw , êh-ntawâpahkêt itah ka-nôtinitowiht . Off he went, to see where his people were fighting.
piyisk aw oskinîkiw wayawîw . At last that youth went out of the tent.
postayôwinisêw , sihkosiwayân , sihkosiwayâninêsâkay ; He dressed, he put on a weaselskin, a weaselskin jacket;
êkwah mitâsah , sihkosiwayâninêtâsah postitâsêw ; and breeches, weaselskin breeches he put on his legs;
êkwah misiwê êh-pîmikitêyikih maskisinah otinam ; postaskisinêw . he took moccasins that were all covered with quillwork; he put on these moccasins.
sîpihkwâpowêyân êkotôwahk otakohpiw awa oskinîkiw kâ-miyosit , kâ-okimâwiyit ôhtâwiya . a blue blanket he had for his robe, that handsome youth whose father was a chieftain.
êkwah otêmah wiyahpitêw ; kaskitêsiyiwa . Then he saddled his horse; it was a black horse.
têhtapiw ; sipwêpayiw , êh-iyihpahtâyit ôh ôtêma . He mounted; he rode away at a trot.

wiyâpamâci owâhkomâkanah ,
hêy , pêyahtik , oma itêh k-êtohtêyin êh-âyimahk ! itik ôwâhkomâkanah . when he saw his relatives, “Hey, go slow; there is danger where you are going!” his relatives said to him.
kîtahtawê kâ-wâpamât êwakonih iskwêyânihk êh-ayâyit ôhih kâ-kîh-kîhkâmikot iskwêwah . Presently, at the very end of the town, there he saw that woman who had taunted him.
nântaw nkotwâsiyiwah iskwêwa . there were half a dozen women.

seg.gloss: “Hey, you have lost your way, Cherry-Tree!

p.seg: itêh k-êtohtêyin namoya kêkway kakîh-wâpahtên iskwêwak osikâkwaniwâwa ! âsay mîna êkos îtik . Where you are going you cannot gee any women's calves!” she said to him again.
hêy , tâpwê mâmaskâc kititâw ! itik wîc-îskwêwah aw îskwêw kâ-miyosit . “Why, strangely are you speaking to him!” the other women said to the handsome one.
mihkwêkin kikasâkêw ; mihkwâpowêyân akwanahôw aw îskwêw , awa k-êtwêt . She wore a jacket of red cloth; a red blanket she had for her robe, that woman, the one who had spoken so.
nama nântaw itwêw awa oskinîkiw kâ-miyosit , ê-kisipiskawât iskwêwah . Not a word said the youth, but went past those women.
êkwah sôhkih pimipayiyiwah . He rode on at a good pace.
nâpêwah pisisik wâpamêw . He saw men all along the way.

êkwah wiyâpamâci owâhkomâkanah ,
pêyahtik , takwahiminânâhtik ! iyinisi ! itik owâhkomâkana otôtêma . Whenever he saw any of his relatives, “Go slow, Cherry-Tree! Be careful!” said his relatives, his kinsmen to him.
nama nântaw itêw . He said nothing to them.
kîtahtawê kâ-pêhtahk êh-ma-matwêwiyik . Presently he heard the sound of firing.
êkwah iyahciyiniwak sakâhk ayâwak , mênisk êh-ayâcik , êh-osîhtâcik . and the Blackfoot were in the wood, where they had made an earthwork.
âsay âtiht pahkwêyawâwak opwâsîmowak ; ayisk kâsôwak ayahciyiniwak . Already some of the Assiniboine had been wounded by bullets; for the Blackfoot were fighting from shelter.
êkwah awa kisêyiniw pêtsâpamêw okosisah , êh-pâpayiyit . Then that old man saw his son riding toward where he was.
nakiskawêw ; otihtêw okosisah . He went to meet him; he went up to his son.
âstam , nikosis ! itêw . “Come here, my son!” he said to him.
êkwah âkawâyihk itohtahêw . Then he led him to a sheltered place.
hâw , nikosis , nîhtakosi , itêw . “Now, my son, dismount!” he told him.
apiw êkotah awa oskinîkiw . The youth sat down there.

seg.gloss: “My son, give me your gun and your ammunition sack.”

p.seg: kêcikonam . He undid them.
apiyiwa . The son sat there.
pâskisikan sipwêhtatâw . He carried the gun away.
haw , wâpamêw oskinîkiwa , cîkahikan-pakamâkan êh-ayâyit . He saw a young man who had a tomahawk.

seg.gloss: “Here is a gun!
Now, young man, use it in return.

p.seg: awihin oma kicîkahikanis , itêw ; Lend me this tomahawk of yours,” he said to him;

seg.gloss: “Not because I think you l aboard, am I borrowing this tomahawk of yours; but because I am thinking, 'perhaps my son will come to close quarters.'”

p.seg: êhag ; otinah ; âpacihtâh , itik ôh oskinîkiwa . “Very well; take it; use it,” the young man answered him.
êkwah okosisa otihtêw . Then he went to his son.

seg.gloss: “Now, my son, take off your clothes!”

p.seg: kêtayôwinisêw . He took off his clothes.
ôhih kâ-miywâsiniyikih otayôwinisah kêcikonam kahkiyaw êwakoni , êh-mosêskatêt aw oskinîkiw . The youth took off all those fine clothes of his, until he was naked.
êkwah ôhtâwiyah wâpatoniskinik misiwê wiyawihk , ohkwâkanihk ; Then his father painted him white all over his body and on his face;
wêstakayah âpahamiyiwa ohtâwiyah , ospiskwanihk êh-astâyit . his father undid his hair for him and placed it at his back.

seg.q: hâw , nkosis , ôma kâ-nêyâskwêyâk , êkotah kakwê-otihtah ê-tâh-tapasîhk , kinwês ka-pimâtisihk , namoya pêyahtik êh-pimohtêhk .
seg.gloss: “Now, my son, try to reach that point of the woods, where men dodge and flee that life may be the longer, where walking is not slow.
Thus you will do;

seg.q: nântaw kêkway wâpahtamanih , pêyak om ohc kika-cîkahên ayîsiyiniw-mistikwân ;
seg.gloss: when you see that which I need not name, with this sole weapon you will cut a human head;

seg.q: êkwah kîh-tôtaman , kik-ôtinên tahto kêkway êh-ayât .
seg.gloss: and when you have done this, you will take as many things as he has.
You will come back here; to this place you will come.

p.seg: hâw , nkosis , nya ! itêw . Now, my son, be off!” he bade him.
êkwah awa moskistam oma sakâw . Then he attacked the wood.

kêkâc ê-sêskisit , kâ-pâskiswât , aspin ê-sêskisit . When he had almost disappeared among the trees, he was fired at, and then he went out of sight. LB on {kâ-pâskiswât}: I have translated as though it were {kâ-pâskisoht}, for I do not understand the form in the text: “he shot (with gun) at the other(s).”
pâskisikan pê-tahkonam . êkwah ayôwinisah êkwah ôma misiwê ostikwân . he held a gun as he came, and clothes, and an entire head.
âsay misiwê mihkoh wiyâhk ayâyiw . Blood was all over his body.
êkwah ôhtâwiyah otihtêw . Then he went to where his father was.

ômis îtik :
nkosis , apih
itik . The latter said to him, “My son, sit down!”
sipwêhtêw awa kisêyiniw . The old man went away.

seg.gloss: “Now, Assiniboine men, you see what my son has done.
So now he has done nobly.”

p.seg:
âsay êkwah kotak oskinîkiw câpihcikanis êh-tahkonahk oskinîkiw ,
awihin ôma ; Then to another young man, who was holding a spear, “Lend me this;

seg.gloss: use these arrows instead as your weapon.

p.seg:
namoya êh-nêsowêyimitân ; mâka
mâskôc kisiwâk osâpahkêcih nikosis , êh-itêyihtamân , k-ôh-ntâhtâmitân , itêw . Not that I think you laggard, but because I think, 'No doubt my son will come to close quarters,' is why I ask the loan of you,” he told him.
êkosi ntawi-miyêw okosisah . Thereupon he went and gave it to his son.

êkosi ,
hâw , nkosis , tahto-kîsikâw wiyâs kâ-wâpahtamêk , mâka wiy ôma nôtinitowin namoya tahto-kîsikâw . Then, “Now, my son, you folk see meat every day, but not every day this fighting.

seg.gloss: Try to get near the place where they are dwelling.

p.seg: ôma âpacihtâh câpihcikanis , itêw okosisah ; Use this spear,” he told his son;
êh-tâh-tapasîhk , kinwês kâ-pimâtisihk , mâka ka-wîcêtin , itêw okosisah . “where men dodge and flee that life may be the longer, - but I shall go with you,” he told his son.
êkwah cîkahikan tahkonam pakamâkan awa kisêyiniw okimâw . Then that old man, the chief, took in his hand a tomahawk.
êkwah nîkânohtêw awa oskinîkiw , nâway ohtâwiya . In front walked the youth; behind, his father.
namoya wî-nakîwak . They had it not in mind to halt.
môskîstamâhkok ! itwêwak ôki opwâsîmowak . “Attack their stronghold!” cried the Assiniboine.
êkosi êw-otihtahkik oma mênisk , konta papêtikopayihowak ôki iyahciyiniwak . And then, when they reached the earthwork, the Blackfoot merely threw themselves down and crouched.
tâh-tahkamêw ; êkos îsi kahkiyaw mêscihimâwa . He stabbed one after another; he left not one of them alive.
êkwah kîwêwak . Then they went back.
wâpowayân paskitastêyiw . a blanket lay across its back.
êkwah kîwêpayiw awa oskinîkiw wîwah kâ-miyosiyit . Then back rode also the youth whose wife was beautiful.

seg.gloss: “Go to meet him.
For now a man has outdone me.

p.seg: tâpiskôc iskwêw niya , itêw owîkimâkanah . Like a woman am I,” he told his wife.
êhag , itik . “So be it,” she answered him.
êkwah nakiskawêw ôhi oskinîkiwah kâ-kîh-nâh-nêpêwimât ; ocêmêw itah ê-nakiskawât . Then she met that youth whom she had shamed by her speech; she kissed him where she met him.
êkwah awa oskinîkiw miyêw otêmah ôhi kâ-mihkawikiyit ôma kiki mîkis-akohp ; Then the youth gave her that swift horse of his, together with the beaded blanket;
êkwah iyiniwistikwân miyêw ôh îskwêwa aw ôskinîkiw kâ-miyosit . and a human head he gave to that woman, did that handsome youth.
êh-tipiskâyik : pê-ntomâw êkotah ôhi kâ-kîh-nâh-nêpêwimikot . At nightfall he was sent for and invited to the tent of her who had put him to shame with words.

êh-pîhtokêt ,
hâ , nisîm , êkotah anohc apih . When he entered, “Ah, my younger brother, do you now sit here.”
an îtah k-âpit iskwêw , êkotah apiw aw ôskinîkiw . Even where that woman sat, there sat that youth.

seg.gloss: “Now, O my younger brother, I give you this person here.
Here at the center of the village you shall live.

p.seg: ka-pamihitinâwâw ; nika-kîsitêpon , itêw . l will care for your needs; I shall cook,” he told him.
êkosi tôtam ; pamihêw . He did even so; he cared for all his needs.
êkwah tâpiskôc miyosiwak ôki ayîsiyiniwak . And equally handsome were those men.
êkwah nêpâtwâwi , wiyâpaniyiki , kîsitêpôw awa kotak kâ-mêkit wîwah . And when they had slept, of a morning, that other would cook who had given away his wife.
nicawâc ê-kiskêyimiht , kotakah miyâw iskwêwah . When it was known that he had done this, he was given another woman.
nîsokamikisiwak pîhtêyis ociwâmah okosâka . They had their two tents in the center of the town, he and his brother, the husband of his wife.
êkwah awa oskinîkiw kâ-miyosit namoya pisikwâtisiw ; kiyâm nipâwak pêyak askiy . But that handsome youth was not forward; they slept there, and no more, for a year.

êkwah êh-âkwâ-nîpiniyik , kîtahtawê kâ-mâtot aw îskwêw , êkâ êh-owîcimosihk , âtah êh-wîhpêmât ôhi kâ-miyosiyit oskinîkiwa ; Then, when summer came again, presently that woman wept, because there was no love-making, even though she slept in one tent with that handsome youth;
nêpêwisiw , ê-kîh-mâh-mây-îtikot ôhi kâ-wîwit . he still felt shame at the repeated evil words she had spoken to him, she who now was his wife.
ncawâc ostêsah ntomêw . At last he called his elder brother.

seg.q: hâw , nstêsê , awa kîwa kiyaskoc kimiyitin .
seg.gloss: “Now, O my elder brother, this your wife I give back to you.
She is too easily brought to tears.

seg.q:
niya ,
namoya êkotê kîc-iskwêwak ayâwak , ê-kîh-isit , namoya nîc-iskwêw ta-kî-pisiskêyimak , ta-kîh-wîwiyân .
seg.gloss: I, to whom she said, 'Not here are your fellow-women,' I cannot fancy my fellow-woman or have her to wife.
From the time when you gave her to me, never have I made love to her.
That is why she has no child.
That is why she weeps all the time.”

seg.q: êhag , nisîm , mâka êkâ wiya sâkwêyimô ;
seg.gloss: “Very well, my brother, but do not withdraw your goodwill;
stay here in my house;
take this other wife of mine.

seg.q: nam êskwa awâsisah ayâwêw êwako mîna .
seg.gloss: This one too has as yet no child.”

p.seg: êhag , itêw . “Very well,” he answered him.
êkosi tâpwê awa kâ-miyosit oskinîkiw kotakah wîwiw ôhi kâ-miyiht . So then the handsome youth took to wife this woman who now was given to him.
kiyipa awâsisah ayâwêwak . Soon they had a child.
êkosi êwako wiya âcimowin ; êkoyikohk êy-iskw-âcimostâtân . So goes this story; now I have told it you to the end.
